transcript.sentence: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Apple Q1 Fiscal Year 2023 Earnings Conference call.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

conceptList.name: Apple Q1 Fiscal Year 2023 Earnings Conference

transcript.sentence: Today's call is being recorded.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And now at this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Tejas Ghala, Director of Investor Relations and Corporate Finance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Please go ahead.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Thank you. first today is Apple CEO Tim Cook, and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: After that, we'll open the call to questions from analysts.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Before turning the call over to Tim, I would like to remind everyone that the December quarter spanned 14 weeks, while the March quarter, as usual, has 13 weeks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding revenue, gross margin, operating expenses, other income and expense, taxes, capital allocation, and the future business outlook, including the potential impact of COVID-19 on the company's business and results of operations.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: These statements involve risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results or trends to differ materially from our forecast.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: For more information, please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today, along with the associated press release.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speak as of their respective dates.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Tejas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Today we're reporting revenue of $117.2 billion for the December quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We set all-time revenue records in a number of markets, including Canada, Indonesia, Mexico, Spain, Turkey, and Vietnam, along with quarterly records in Brazil and India.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: As a result of a challenging environment, our revenue was down 5% year over year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: But I'm proud of the way we have navigated circumstances seen and unforeseen over the past several years, and I remain incredibly confident in our team, in our mission, and in the work we do every day.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Let me discuss the three factors that impacted our revenue performance during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The first was foreign exchange headwinds, which had a nearly 800 basis point impact.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: On a constant currency basis, we grew year over year and would have grown in the vast majority of the markets we track.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The second factor, which we described in a November 6th update, was COVID-19 related challenges, which significantly impacted the supply of iPhone 14 Pro and iPhone 14 Pro Pro Max and lasted through most of December.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Because of these constraints, we had significantly less iPhone 14 Pro and iPhone 14 Pro Max supply than we planned, causing ship times to extend far beyond what we had anticipated.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: As we always have every step of the way throughout the pandemic, we continue to prioritize people and work with our suppliers to ensure the health and safety of every worker.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Production is now back where we want it to be.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The third factor was a challenging macroeconomic environment as the world continues to face unprecedented circumstances, from inflation to war in Eastern Europe to the enduring impacts of the pandemic.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And we know that Apple is not immune to it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: But whatever conditions we face, our approach is always the same.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We are thoughtful and deliberate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We manage for the long term.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We adapt quickly to circumstances outside our control while delivering with excellence in the things we can.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We invest in innovation, in people, and in the positive difference we can make in the world.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And we do it all to provide our customers with technology that will enrich their lives and help unlock their full creative potential.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: It's a wonderful thing to be a part of, and it's so rewarding for all of us at Apple when we hear how much our customers are loving what we create.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Let me talk now about what we saw across our product categories.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Starting with iPhone, revenue came in at $65.8 billion for the quarter, down 8% year over year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: However, on a constant currency basis, iPhone revenue was roughly flat.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Our customers continue to rave about the astounding camera capabilities and unprecedented battery life and the groundbreaking suite of health and safety features.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The iPhone 14 lineup pushes the limits of what users can do with a smartphone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: During the quarter, Mac revenue came in at $7.7 billion, which was in line with what we had expected.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We had a difficult compare because this time last year we had the extremely successful launch of the redesigned M1 MacBook Pros.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We also faced a challenging macroeconomic environment and foreign exchange headwinds.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We remain confident in and focused on the long-term opportunity for Mac.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Just last month, we introduced new MacBook Pro models powered by our latest developments in Apple Silicon, M2 Pro and M2 Max.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: These chips enable unprecedented performance and do so with less energy, which is not only good for the environment, but gives the newest MacBook Pro the longest battery life ever in a Mac.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We also introduced the M2-powered Mac Mini, which will supercharge productivity for users of all kinds and leave them stunned by just how powerful a Mac Mini can be.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: During the quarter, iPad revenue grew 30% to a total of $9.4 billion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The very strong growth was due in part to a favorable compare to the December quarter a year ago when we experienced significant supply constraints.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Customers continue to praise our new lineup for its versatility, whether it's the new iPad Pro, now powered by the M2, or the newly designed iPad 10th generation with its stunning liquid retina display and beautiful colors.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Revenue for wearables, home, and accessories was $13.5 billion, which was down 8% year over year, driven by foreign exchange headwinds and a challenging macroeconomic environment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We remain excited about the long-term opportunity in the category.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: As an example, a few weeks ago, we announced the Next Generation HomePod, which is an indispensable addition to the smart home.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: This powerful smart speaker relies on advanced computational audio to produce an incredible listening experience.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We're also helping users make their homes safer with sound recognition.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: This feature, arriving later this spring, allows HomePod to send a notification directly to a user's iPhone if a smoke or carbon monoxide alarm sound is identified.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We continue to hear wide praise for Apple Watch Series 8 and Apple Watch Ultra, which has set a new standard for what's possible with a wearable.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: From a whole host of health and safety features to incredible new capabilities for extreme athletes, there is something for everyone in these amazing products.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Customers are excited about some phenomenal new features we've made available across many of our products as well.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: One of the highlights is emergency SOS via satellite, which launched for iPhone 14 customers in the U.S. and Canada in November, and for customers in France, Germany, Ireland, and the U.K. in December.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: This is a feature we hope our users will never need, but it is incredibly heartening to get e-mails from people describing the life-saving impact our new safety features have had on them.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We're always looking for new ways to empower people to create and collaborate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: In December, we released Freeform, a brand new app that lets users take their ideas wherever they want, anywhere they are, all while collaborating in real time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Freeform has already received praise from reviewers for its flexibility and simplicity as it works seamlessly across iPhone, iPad, and Mac.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Today we are very excited to announce that we've achieved a truly incredible milestone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks to our deep commitment to innovation, incredible customer loyalty and satisfaction, and a large number of switchers, we now have more than 2 billion active devices as part of our growing installed base, double what it was just seven years ago.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: This is an incredible testament to our products and services and the strength of our ecosystem.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We set an all-time revenue record of $20.8 billion in services, which was better than what we had expected.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We achieved double-digit revenue growth from App Store subscriptions and set all-time revenue records across a number of categories, including cloud and payment services.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: All told, Apple now has more than 935 million paid subscriptions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Apple has also just begun a historic 10-year partnership with Major League Soccer.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Just yesterday, we launched MLS Season Pass, which will give fans in more than 100 countries access to every live MLS regular season game, as well as the playoffs and MLS Cup, all with no blackouts.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And while we're providing more content to sports fans than ever before, Apple TV Plus continues to showcase powerful characters and moving storytelling.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We were thrilled to celebrate the holidays alongside our Apple TV Plus subscribers with the hit movie, Spirited, and we're delighted to see how much people are enjoying new and returning series like Shrinking, Slow Horses, and Truth Be Told.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And we have some great upcoming movies in Sharper and Tetris, along with Emmy Award winner Ted Lasso returning this spring.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: During the quarter, we made some great updates to Fitness Plus as well, expanding our catalog of more than 3,500 workouts and meditations to include a new kickboxing category and a new sleep theme for meditations.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Our latest Artist Spotlight series features the music of the incomparable Beyonce, and we're excited to take a stroll with guests appearing on our fifth season of Time to Walk.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And we continued to build on our decades-long commitment to helping small businesses thrive when we announced Apple Business Connect.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: This new tool gives business owners even more control over how billions of people see and engage with their products and services every day.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Users of all sizes can now customize key information for users across Apple Maps, Messages, Wallet, Siri, and other apps.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Meanwhile, in retail, we celebrated 25 years of the Apple Online Store and also opened Apple Pacific Center in Vancouver and Apple American Dream in New Jersey.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And I'm grateful to all the teams who helped our customers throughout the busy holiday season.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: At Apple, we spend a lot of time focused on creating an unparalleled experience for our customers and every product and service that we offer.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We're also just as dedicated to leading with our values in everything we do.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: As part of that work, we strengthened our deep commitment to privacy and security, giving users three new tools to protect their most sensitive data, iMessage contact key verification, security keys for Apple ID, and advanced data protection for iCloud.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: At Apple, we feel a deep sense of responsibility to lead the world better than we found it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We're also a year closer to 2030, and we remain ever focused on the environmental commitments we set out for the end of the decade.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: As an example, the latest Mac Mini and MacBook Pro models all use 100% recycled aluminum in the enclosure and recycled rare earth elements in all magnets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And in a first for HomePod, we're using 100% recycled gold in the plating of multiple printed circuit boards.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: In honor of Black History Month, we released the Black Unity Collection, including the a special edition Apple Watch Black Unity Sport Loop, a new matching watch face and iPhone wallpaper.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

conceptList.name: Apple Watch Black Unity Sport Loop

transcript.sentence: Through our racial equity and justice initiative, we're expanding our support of five organizations focused on lifting up communities of color through technology.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We are committed as ever to building on our progress around inclusion and diversity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: During the quarter, we also announced that since the inception of our giving program 11 years ago, we've donated more than $880 million to humanitarian efforts, disaster relief, childhood education, and more.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And over the last 16 years, through our partnership with REDD, Apple-supported grants have helped more than 11 million people get the care and support services they need.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: As we look ahead in 2023, We are excited about the year to come.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: At Apple, we are always looking forward, always focused on the next challenge, always determined to do great things with unmatched creativity and unrivaled innovation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And that makes me more confident about the future of Apple than I have ever been.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: With that, I'll turn it over to Luca.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Tim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And good afternoon, everyone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: As Tim mentioned, revenue for the December quarter was $117.2 billion, down 5% from last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: A number of factors had a significant impact on our results.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: First, we faced a very difficult foreign exchange environment, which affected our performance by nearly 800 basis points.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In other words, we grew revenue on a constant currency basis.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And in fact, we did so in the vast majority of markets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Second, the macroeconomic environment this past quarter was markedly more challenging than 12 months ago.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Third, we experienced significant supply shortages for iPhone 14 Pro and iPhone 14 Pro Max in November and through December.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: On the other hand, we had the positive impact of the 14th week in the quarter that Tejas mentioned at the beginning of the call.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Products revenue was $96.4 billion, down 8% from last year, due to the factors I just called out.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: At the same time, however, our installed base of active devices grew double digits and achieved all-time records in each geographic segment and in each major product category.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We are proud to now have over 2 billion active devices in our installed base.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: This continued growth in the installed base is due to extremely strong levels of customer satisfaction and loyalty and a high number of customers who are new to our products.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The installed base growth also helped our services set an all-time revenue record of $20.8 billion, up 6% over a year ago.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We achieved this new milestone despite more than 700 basis points of negative impact from foreign exchange.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We reached all-time services revenue records in the Americas, Europe, and rest of Asia-Pacific, and a December quarter record in Greater China.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We also set records in many services categories, including all-time revenue records for cloud services, payment services, and music, and December quarter records for the App Store and Apple Care.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Company gross margin was 43 percent, up 70 basis points from last quarter, due to leverage and favorable mix, partially offset by foreign exchange.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Products gross margin was 37%, up 240 basis points sequentially, and services gross margin was 70.8%, up 30 basis points sequentially, both due to the same factors that impacted total company gross margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Operating expenses of $14.3 billion were significantly below the guidance range we provided at the beginning of the quarter, and grew at a slower pace than in the past, as we took actions to respond to the current macro environment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Net income was $30 billion, diluted earnings per share were $1.88, and we generated very strong operating cash flow of $34 billion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Let me now get into more detail for each of our revenue categories. iPhone revenue was 65.8 billion, despite significant foreign exchange headwinds, supply constraints on iPhone 14 Pro and iPhone 14 Pro Max, and a challenging macroeconomic environment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In spite of these circumstances, we set all-time iPhone revenue records in Canada, Italy, and Spain and saw strong growth in several emerging markets, including all-time iPhone revenue records for India and Vietnam.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Importantly, the installed base of active iPhones continues to grow nicely and is at an all-time high across all geographic segments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In emerging markets in particular, the installed base grew double digits, and we had record levels of switchers in India and in Mexico.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Our customers continue to love their experience with our products, with the latest survey of U.S. consumers from 451 research indicating customer satisfaction on 98% for the iPhone 14 family.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Mac revenue was 7.7 billion, down 29% year over year, and in line with our expectations.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: There were three key drivers for our Mac results.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: First, we had a challenging compare against last year's launch of the completely reimagined MacBook Pros, our first notebooks with M1 Pro and M1 Max.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Second, we believe that the macro environment impacted our Mac performance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And third, we faced significant foreign exchange headwinds.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: At the same time, however, the installed base of active Macs reached an all-time high across all geographic segments and we continue to see very strong upgraded activity to Apple Silicon.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Customer satisfaction with Mac remains very strong at 96% based on the latest survey of U.S. consumers from 451 research. iPad revenue was 9.4 billion, up 30% year over year, despite significant FX headwinds.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: This performance was driven by two key items.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: First, during the December quarter a year ago, we experienced significant supply constraints, while this year, we had enough supply to meet demand.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Second, we launched our new iPad and the iPad Pro powered by the M2 chip during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The iPad install base reached a new all-time high thanks to incredible customer loyalty and a high number of new customers.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In fact, over half of the customers who purchased iPads during the quarter were new to the product.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Wearables, home, and accessories revenue was $13.5 billion, down 8% year-over-year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The year-over-year decline was driven by significant FX headwinds and a challenging macroeconomic environment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: However, our installed base of devices in the category set a new all-time record, thanks to the largest number of customers new to a smartwatch that we've ever had in a given quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In fact, nearly 2 thirds of customers purchasing an Apple Watch during the quarter were new to the product.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Moving to services, we generated $20.8 billion in revenue, a new all-time record in total, and for many services offerings, in spite of a difficult foreign exchange environment and macroeconomic headwinds impacting certain categories, such as digital advertising and mobile gaming.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In constant currency, we grew services revenue double digits on top of growing 24% during the December quarter a year ago.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We remain focused on the large long-term opportunity in this category, and we continue to observe several trends that reflect the strength of our ecosystem.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For example, we saw increased customer engagement with our services during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Both our transacting accounts and paid accounts grew double digits year over year, each setting a new all-time record.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Paid subscriptions also continue to grow nicely.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We now have more than 935 million paid subscriptions across the services on our platform, up more than 150 million during the last 12 months alone, and nearly four times what we had just five years ago.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And we continue to increase the reach and improve the quality of our offerings.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For instance, Apple Pay is now available to millions of merchants in nearly 70 countries and regions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And we saw a record-breaking number of purchases made using Apple Pay globally during the holiday shopping season.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Finally, our installed base of over 2 billion active devices represents a great foundation for future expansion of our ecosystem.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And it continues to grow even during difficult macroeconomic conditions, which speaks to the exceptionally high levels of customer loyalty and satisfaction and our ability to attract new customers to our platform.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The growth is coming from every major product category and geographic segment, with strong double-digit increases in emerging markets, such as Brazil, Mexico, India, Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Turning to the enterprise market, we are seeing continued adoption of our services for business, like Apple Business Essentials, AppleCare, Tap2Pay, and Apple Financial Services.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For example, Mars Incorporated has expanded its use of AppleCare for Enterprise to provide timely device support and assurance for iPads deployed across their manufacturing sites.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Meanwhile, HCA Healthcare has leveraged Apple Financial Services to manage the annual refresh of its entire fleet of iPhones.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: This not only ensures that their staff stay current on the latest Apple technology, but also provides them with significant annual savings in the process.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Let me now turn to our capital return program and our cash position.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We returned over $25 billion to shareholders during the December quarter as our business continues to generate very strong cash flow.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: This included $3.8 billion in dividends and equivalents and $19 billion through open market repurchases of 133 million Apple shares.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We ended the quarter with $165 billion in cash and marketable securities.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We repaid $1.4 billion in maturing debt and decreased commercial paper by $8.2 billion, leaving us with total debt of $111 billion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: As a result, net cash was $54 billion at the end of the quarter, and we maintain our goal of becoming net cash neutral over time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: As we move into the March quarter, I'd like to review our outlook, which includes the the types of forward-looking information that Tejas referred to at the beginning of the call.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Given the continued uncertainty around the world in the near term, we are not providing revenue guidance, but we are sharing some directional insights based on the assumption that the microeconomic outlook and COVID-related impacts to our business do not worsen from what we are projecting today for the current quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In total, we expect our March quarter year-over-year revenue performance to be similar to the December quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: This represents an acceleration in our underlying year-over-year business performance, as the December quarter benefited from an extra week.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For an exchange, we'll continue to be a headwind, and we expect a negative year-over-year impact of five percentage points.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For services, we expect revenue to grow year over year while continuing to face macroeconomic headwinds in areas such as digital advertising and mobile gaming.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For iPhone, we expect our March quarter year over year revenue performance to accelerate relative to the December quarter year over year revenue performance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For Mac and iPad, we expect revenue for both product categories to decline double digits year over year because of challenging compares and macroeconomic headwinds.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We expect gross margin to be between 43.5 percent and 44.5 percent.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: We expect OPEX to be between $13.7 and $13.9 billion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We expect OI&E to be around negative $100 million, excluding any potential impact from the mark-to-market of minority investments and our tax rate to be around 16 percent.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Finally, today our board of directors has declared a cash dividend of 23 cents per share of common stock payable on February 16, 2023 to shareholders of record as of February 13, 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: With that, let's open the call to questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Luca.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We ask that you limit yourself to two questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Operator, may we have the first question, please?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Certainly.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We'll go ahead and take our first question from David Vought with UBS.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks, guys, for taking my question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: So, Tim, and maybe this is for Luca as well, you talked about the supply chain returning back to normal after a very difficult October-November, but we're still seeing some disruptions across tech products, whether it's enterprise or consumer-facing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: How do you think about your supply chain and maybe the levels of inventory or bills that you might need as we go forward to sort of insulate your business from these sort of episodic disruptions?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Have you changed your view?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And if so, how does that affect, you know, ultimately, margins and sort of your balance sheet and cash flow items going forward?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Uh, this is Tim, David. uh, from a supply point of view, we, we did see disruption from, uh, early November through, um, through, uh, most of December.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And, um, the, from a supply, from a supply chain point of view, we're now at a point where, uh, production is what we need it to be.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: And so the, the problem is behind us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: In terms of going forward in the supply chain, you know, we build our products everywhere.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: There are component parts coming from many different countries in the world, and the final assembly coming from three countries in the world and on just iPhone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And so, we continue to optimize it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We'll continue to optimize it over time and and change it to continue to improve.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I think when you zoom out and back up from it, the last three years have been a pretty difficult time between COVID and silicon shortages and the like.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I think we have had a very resilient supply chain in the aggregate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: In terms of supply for this quarter, which I think was one of your, your points.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I, I think we're in a decent supply on most products.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For the quarter currently.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Great, thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Yeah, great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thanks.

transcript.sentence: Can we have the next question?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Please.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Our next question is from Shannon Cross of Credit Suisse.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Luca, I wanted to dig a bit more into the commentary on gross margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The guidance, especially at 43.5 to 44.5, is obviously quite strong.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: So I'm wondering what's helping you out there to mix in some other things.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And then, you know, how should we think about what currency and hedging is going to do as we look forward?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: And then I have a follow-up.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Yep. Shannon?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Yes, I mean, we've had good margin for the December quarter to start with.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: We reported 43 percent.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Obviously, in December, we had the benefit of leverage because of the seasonality of the business, but we also had favorable mix across the board.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Of course, foreign exchange is an issue right now.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: In the December quarter, on a sequential basis, foreign exchange was a negative 110 basis points for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And on a year-over-year basis, it's 300 basis points.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: So obviously, the FX environment has changed a lot during the last 12 months.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: For March, yeah, we've seen a margin expansion, 43.5 to 44.5. We're doing a lot of work around cost, of course.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Mix will continue to help, both within categories and services mix, as we move away from the holiday season.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: But we're doing a lot of work on the cost structure, and that is paying off.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Foreign exchange is still a negative, about 50 basis points sequentially, but it's mitigating.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The last couple of weeks, the dollar has weakened a bit, and so hopefully, as we go through the year, hopefully things will improve.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: But for now, as you correctly state, we are in a good position on margins.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And then, Tim, can you talk a bit about China?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: You know, what you're seeing – obviously, you've had the issues with production, but I mean more on the demand side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: As, you know, we've gotten through Chinese – or into Chinese New Year and the opening, I'm just wondering, you know, are you seeing the Chinese consumer come back? are they buying and how are you thinking about your position there?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Shannon, last quarter, we declined by 7% on a reported basis, but we actually grew on a constant currency basis.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And that was despite some significant the supply constraints that we talked about earlier.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And obviously, the sort of the COVID restrictions throughout China that happened in various different places throughout the country also impacted the the demand during the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: When you look at the opening that started happening in December, we saw a marked change in traffic in our stores as compared to November and that followed through to demand as well.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And I don't want to get into January.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We've obviously for January is included in the guidance or the color rather that Luca provided earlier.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: But we did see a marked change from December compared to November.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yep.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yep. Great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Shannon.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Can we have the next question, please?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Our next question is from Eric Woodring of Morgan Stanley.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Hey, guys.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks for taking my questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Maybe, Tim, first one for you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: That $2 billion device installed base figure, that's up, I believe, 200 million units year over year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: That implies the strongest annual gain in new devices in your installed base, basically as far back as you've provided those data points.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And so I guess my two questions are, one, can you provide the installed base for the iPhone at year end?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And then two, is there anything that you see in this new cohort of users that might look different or similar to past cohorts, either by, you know, demographic or regions or monetization ramp?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And then I will will follow.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The install base is now over 2 billion active devices as you mentioned and we set records across each geographic segment and major product category and so it was a it was a broad-based change.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: To correct one thing you said it's it's up over a hundred and fifty million year over year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The last report we reported to be over 1.85 and so it's a hundred and fifty which we're which we're very proud of.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We also saw strong double-digit in several of the emerging markets, which is very important to us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: For example, India and Brazil as just two examples.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: So very, very strong and obviously it bodes well for the future.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thank you for the color, Tim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And then, you know, Luca, obviously, the December quarter was negatively impacted by the production challenges.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Can you just maybe unpackage where channel inventory levels are today, kind of across the iPhone broadly?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And then, you know, what the data that you're seeing so far this quarter is telling you about iPhone demand deferral versus kind of iPhone demand destruction and perhaps pushing some upgrades later into the year rather than into the March quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And that's it for me, thanks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yeah, Eric, I'll take that one as well.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The channel inventory levels on iPhone, we obviously ended the December quarter below our target range given the supply challenges on iPhone 14 Pro and iPhone 14 Pro Max.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: But as you think about this, keep in mind that a year ago, we also exited the December quarter below our target inventory range because of supply challenges in the year ago quarter, not related, not the same issue by just as a point.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And so that that hopefully gives you some flavor of that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: In terms of what we're seeing in January, we've included in our color that Luca provided kind of our thinking it's very hard to estimate the recapture because you you have to know exactly what would have happened and how many people bought down and it takes a while to get that to get those reports in during the quarter and and so we've made our best guess at it in terms of sizing of the constraint in Q1, what we estimate, although not with precision, is that we would, I thought, we believe iPhone would have grown during the quarter had had it not been for the supply shortages.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: So hopefully that provides you a little bit of color.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Yep, that's great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thanks so much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Eric.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: can we have the next question please our next question comes from Aaron Rakers of Wells Fargo yeah thanks for taking the question I have two as well if I can I guess the first kind of question I just going back on the gross margin line you know pretty pretty good guidance into this March quarter I'm curious if you unpack that a little bit specific around what you're seeing as far as you know maybe benefits from component pricing, you know, in the guidance, if you're embedding any of that at this point?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Yeah, of course, you know, with our guidance we try to capture every aspect of our cost structure and obviously components are a big portion of that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: So definitely that's included.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: And keep in mind, again, that for an exchange, I mentioned earlier, I think to Shannon, that The sequential negative on FX is 50 basis points, versus a year ago, it's 270 basis points.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Obviously, the U.S. dollar has moved a lot over the last 12 months.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: So obviously, we need to find offsets and more to the negative FX in order to be able to provide this kind of guidance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And so obviously, components are a big part of that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yeah, and then kind of, you know, from a strategic perspective, giving kind of the things that we're seeing out in some of your peer group, I'm curious, Tim, how you think about, you know, the role of AI in your strategy as far as particularly in the services segment, whether you not, you see opportunities to excel monetization abilities within the paid subscriber base and whether or not AI is something that you're implementing a bit more strategically there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yeah, it is a major focus of ours.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: It's incredible in terms of how it can enrich customers' lives and you can look no further than some of the things that we announced in the fall with crash detection and fall detection or back a ways with ECG.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: I mean, and these things have literally saved people's lives.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And so we see an enormous potential in this space to affect virtually everything we do.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: It's obviously a horizontal technology, not a vertical.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And so it will affect every product and every service that we have.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Thanks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Can we have the next question, please?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Certainly.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani of Evercore.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Yep.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Thanks for taking my question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yes, the first one I have is, Tim, I think based on your earlier comments that iPhones would have grown X, the production issue that imply that maybe it's a $7 billion or so impact that you had in December quarter from the production challenges on the high-end models.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: You know, I'm sure it's tough to see what happens this time around, but I think, historically, when you've had, you know, production issues or things like this happen, what has the consumer behavior been typically?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Do they tend to go down towards the lower-end models and get the phone they want quickly, or do they just defraud their production?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Just from a historical perspective, I think, do you typically recover what's defraud out, or no?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: It's very hard to estimate, is the real answer, because you have to know a lot of data and it's usually only in hindsight that you have a more reasonable view of it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And so we put our best views in the color that Luca provided, that's kind of what I would say.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: All right.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: All right, and maybe if I think about services as you go forward, and you've had really good growth in services I think over the last several years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: But as you go forward in services, what do you think drives the growth more so?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Is it the expansion of your install base, or is it more going to be driven by ARPU going higher for you?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I'm just curious, how do you think about those two buckets as you go forward?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I mean, there's a number of things, and I mentioned a few of them during the call.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The first step is always the install base.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The install base is the engine for services growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And the fact that the install base is growing very nicely and it's growing in a lot of emerging markets, it's growing even faster, that gives us a larger addressable pool of customers.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: So that's incredibly important.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The second one is that we're seeing that the level of engagement of our customers already in our ecosystem continues to grow.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I mentioned that both transacting accounts and paid accounts grew double digits, so that bodes very well for the future.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And we have a lot of transacting accounts that can move to paid accounts over time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: The other aspect that is very important for us is to continue constantly to improve the reach and the quality of our services.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And I gave the example of Apple Pay, which it's a great example because, you know, we started off primarily in the United States, now we've taken it to 70 markets, millions of merchants.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And so obviously, payment services continue to set new highs all the time for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And as you've seen over the last few years, we also launched new services over time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And that obviously contributes to the growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: We're very excited, and when we look at the behavior of our installed base, we think it's very promising for the continued growth of our services business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Perfect.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Amit.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Can we have the next question, please?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Our next question comes from Harsh Kumar of Piper Sandler.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Yeah.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Hey, Tim, I had a quick question on emerging markets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Seems like you're making a lot of strides in India.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: Potentially wanted to understand the kind of share you have in China and India.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: And relative to that, what would be your aspirational but sort of achievable share in iPhones in those territories, whether it's units or revenues?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And I was hoping to draw on your experience of maybe what you've seen in other countries where you've had some longer presence.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: In looking at the business in India, we set a quarterly revenue record and grew very strong, double digits year over year, and so we feel very good about how we performed, and that's despite the headwinds that we've talked about.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Taking a step back, India is a hugely exciting market for us and is a major focus.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: We brought the online store there in 2020.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: We will soon bring Apple retail there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: So we're putting a lot of emphasis on the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: There's been a lot done from a financing options and and trade-ins to make products more affordable and give people more options to buy.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And so there's a lot going on there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: We're in essence taking what we learned in China years ago and how we scaled China and bringing that to bear.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And I don't have the exact market shares in front of me, but I think you would see that from a market share point of view that we grew around the world last quarter on iPhone, despite the challenges that we had on the supply side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: And I wouldn't expect to have a difference in those two markets. understood and for my follow-up I had a sort of a interesting theoretical question on pricing assuming we get the CHIP Act passed and there's a whole bunch of manufacturing that happens in US and other territories that are potentially somewhat more expensive than the ones you might be in now have you has the company done any studies to gauge the elasticity of demand relative to small price increases in your products?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_09

transcript.sentence: We have experience in that, but I wouldn't necessarily draw the same conclusion that you have in terms of the cost of the product.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We don't know at this point exactly what that will be, but we're all in, in terms of being the largest customer for TSMC in Arizona, and we're very proud to take part in that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: That's what I would say about that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Okay.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Fair enough.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thank you, Tim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Yep.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: the next question please character question comes from one of them on the bank of america uh... yes thank you uh... at them you've got a phenomenal job of driving consumer choice towards higher end products within your portfolio how would you compare this cycle for our phones if you were to segment the pro versus non-pro models versus the cycles from from the past few years and And do you think this move to higher ASBs is sustainable, or do you think it reverses in a tighter consumer spending environment?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I have a follow-up.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The pro has been a 14 pro, and the 14 pro max have done extremely well up until the point where we had a supply shortage and couldn't provide them, couldn't provide the total of the demand.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And so, it's definitely a strong pro-cycle.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: I think there's a number of reasons for that, but the most important one is always the product.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And I think the innovations in the product speak for themselves.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And we feel, you know, very good about the product that we announced back in September and are happy to now be at a point where we're shipping to the demand.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And Tim, do you think that this move to sort of higher ASPs that has happened over the last few years is sustainable or could it sustain in this, you know, very tough macro environment that you've cited?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I wouldn't want to predict, but I would say that the smartphone for us the iPhone has become so integral into people's lives, you know, it contains their contacts and their health information and their banking information and their smart home and so many different parts of their lives.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: It's their payment vehicle and for many people and so I think people are willing to to really stretch to get the best they can they can afford in that category okay great and and temp you you clearly emphasize the focus and importance of the install base if we think about the absolute grip of the install base from a billion to two billion over seven years from a device standpoint how how should we think about the penetration of services or the growth in paying customers on services over that time frame?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Is that penetration rate increasing or decreasing?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: How fast is that growing relative to the growth of the overall install base?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I want to see.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's Luca.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Yes, of course, we keep track of that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: It's really, really important for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Over the last seven years, as we've doubled the install base, we've seen a growing engagement of our customers on the platform.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: That happens, first of all, by customers transacting on the platform and then moving to paid accounts, so starting to pay for some of the services.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: That percentage of paid accounts tends to grow over time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: We've seen it in developed markets, we see it in emerging markets, and that is due to some of the reasons that I was explaining earlier, including the fact that we made it easier for our customers to get engaged on the platform.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: For example, we offer multiple payment methods in many countries.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And we've made it easier to explore for more services because we've added a lot of services on the platform over the last seven years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: So to your question, of course, higher engagement means a higher percentage of paid accounts over time.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Okay, thank you Luca.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: All right, thanks, Wamsi.

transcript.sentence: We saw very good results in our cloud services business, in payment services, music was very strong.

transcript.sentence: So we had a number of categories that set new records, all-time records, and they did a bit better than we were expecting at the beginning of the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And so Tim mentioned it during, I think, his prepared remarks that When you look at it in constant currency, we grew services double digits, and that was on top of a 24% increase a year ago.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: So it's very sustained growth that we're seeing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thank you so much, and congratulations to you and all your teams.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_12

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Jim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Can we have the next question, please?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Our next question will come from Krish Sankar of Cowen & Company.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: Hi, thanks for taking my question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: I had two of them.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: The first one, Tim or Luke, you mentioned how the macro did soften and had an impact.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: And as consumers tighten their belt, when you look across your hardware products and service businesses, where have you seen the biggest impact and where have you seen the least impact from the softening macro?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: And then I had a quick follow-up.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: We think there was some impact across the products and in services.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Probably the ones that we saw the most impact on were Mac and wearables.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: You can see that in those numbers. and probably the least would have been iPhone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Got it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Got it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Very helpful, Tim.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And then just a quick follow-up on the Mac, you know, the PC industry is expecting decline in PC shipments this year also.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: How to think about the Mac relative to kind of like where the PC industry as a whole is expecting the shipments to end up?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: Is there any color you can give on that?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: Thank you very much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The industry is very challenged, as you say.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: The industry is contracting.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: I think from us, though, and I don't know how this year will play out, so I don't want to predict the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: But over the long run, we have a market that is a reasonable-sized market, a big market, And we have low share.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And we have a competitive advantage with Apple Silicon.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And so strategically, I think we're well positioned in the market, albeit I think it will be a little rough in the short term.

transcript.sentence: Yep.
